Would later become chief banking aide
Sedlmayr begins working for DeConcini full time
Jacobson starts working for Cranston (on Senate staff)
DeConcini meets Keating for the first time at a party
McCain meets Keating for the first time
DeConcini endorces Keating for Bahamas ambassadorship in letter to President
Keating gives money to McCain's 1st House campaign
DeConcini asks Keating to help with fundraising for his '82 Senate campaign
Ed Gray becomes Chariman of the FHLBB
Keating gives money to McCain's 2nd House campaign
DeConcini's office (Sedlmayr) starts dealing with Keating
Sending messages to other Senators on his behalf
Jacobson leaves Senate staff and becomes "Fundraising Coordinator" for Cranston
Keating arranges for contributions to retire Glenn's '84 presidential debt
McCain meets with Keating socially in Phoenix
Sedlmayr prepares letter to Gray requesting delay of new regulations
Glenn sends letter to Gray re:dissatisfaciton w/Direct Investment law.
Cranston and Jacobson meets Grogan at Democratic National Convention
Grogan says Keating could help clear Cranston's presidential bid bebt (they later later send $10,000 in individual contributions)
Cranston, Jordan, and Grogan meet re: possible "direct investment" laws
FHLBB was thinking of regulating the amount of investment thrifts could directly make in real estate ventures following the S&L deregulation law
Attends meeting with Alan Greenspan, Grogan, and Cranston
Greenspan does investigation of Lincoln and endorses their "direct investment" practices
Updates Glenn on his investigation and endorsement of Lincoln (unkown if Grogan was there)
Glenn sends further letter to Gray re: dissatisfaciton with possible "direct investment" laws
DeConcini asks Keating to serve on Finance Committee of his '88 reelection campaign

Under the new rule, effective April 16, the amount of direct investment that a thrift would be allowed to make will be tied to its net worth. Formerly, institutions with a relatively low level of net worth could make direct investment up to 10% of net assets without obtaining regulatory approval
Media: Everything's Black and White When It Comes to Ed Gray

Mortgage-industry insiders are still talking about the performance that savings and loan regulatory czar Edwin J. Gray gave last March before a prestigious group of about 100 industry executives regarding "direct investment" laws.
Keating and Grogan organize a fundraiser for Cranston
DeConcini writes letters to the Treasury Secretary re: various complaints about Gray
Write Keating and lets him know that he has made these complaints
Keating contributes to a political action committee (PAC) that Glenn is the spokesman for
Keating attempts to hire Gray out of regulatory role (as FHLBB Chairman)
Gray reports Keating to the Justice Department
Keating gives money to McCain's 1st Senate campaign
Keating offers to raise more, but McCain declines. Over four campaigns, Keating will contribute $4,000 personally with $112,000 coming from family and friends
Jacobson starts $300,000 line of credit from Lincoln

To finance Cranston's '86 re-election campaign. Cranston faced a campaign debt of $2 million from his '84 presidential campaign and had to quickly gear up for an expensive and competitive re-election battle in '86
Keating again contributes to a political action committee (PAC) that Glenn is the spokesman for
Riegle meets Keating at the opening of his Detroit Ponchetrain Hotel
Glenn tells Riegle to go and meet Keating as a potential funder. They do not talk about Lincoln's problems
Keating asks Glenn to support nomination of Lee Henkel to Bank Board
Media: Earnings, Revenue Rise 30% for Lincoln Savings
Media: FHLBB's Gray Fights On; S&L Officials No Longer Pressing for His Resignation

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, ankle-deep in rumors that he would announce his resignation, stood at a lectern in Dallas last November while looking across an audience of the thrift industry's top executives.
DeConcini recomends Henkel to be on the FHLBB
Keating suggests him, DiConcini writes Riegle about it. Sedlmayr notes these requests are unusal
Keating asks Glenn to support the nomination of Daniel Manion
Keating, Grogan, and Riegle meet briefly re: ACC
McCain writes Gray about delaying implementation of "direct investment" regulation
Media: EARNINGS; Lincoln S&L Reports 50% Income Drop

Lincoln Savings & Loan Assn. reported that its net income for the second quarter fell more than 50% to $11.9 million from $24.1 million in the same quarter last year. Revenues in the quarter rose 38.7% to $193.8 million from $139.7 million in last.
DeConcini recieves checks raised by Keating
Totals $16,000. DeConcini says he is aware of these only after the '86 election
Keating, Grogan, and Riegle meet re: Henkel nomination
Sedlmayr becomes aware of Keating's trouble with the Bank Board
Because of media on the matter
Media: FHLBB Officials' Special Treatment Probed

Four top officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board are receiving special treatment that gives two of them salaries that are thousands of dollars above the federal pay cap and provides the other two with job security unavailable to most top officials.
Cirona Report is issued (Gray has access to this)
Outlines in great detail all the problems that the FHLB-SF had with ACC. Contentious because Gray's statement at the first meeting of "I don't know anything" is a sham
FSLIC recapitalization bill is stopped in Congress by Speaker Wright
Signals to Bank Board that Congressional consent will be key to future regulatory efforts
Jacobson meets with Keating on Election Night
Media: Lincoln Savings Reports 70% Gain in Profit for Third Quarter
Media: Gray Reimbursed Home Loan Banks for Wife's Travels

Federal Home Loan Bank Board Chairman Edwin J. Gray on Tuesday made public hundreds of pages of his expense and travel records for meetings ranging from Florida to Hawaii, along with a memo saying that the furor over payment of his wife's travel expenses should subside as he always repaid voluntarily.
Media: Bank Board Lived Well Off S&Ls; Industry Picked Up Tab for Cruises, Gifts, Alcohol, Limousines - Bank Board's Expenses Disclosed
DeConcini sends Sedlmayr memo about putting pressure on Gray
Evidence that they want to get rid of him well before the April meetings
Sedlmayr advises DeConcini to "stay out of" the Gray/Keating feud
Jacobson sends memo to Cranston re: legislative matters of contributors
Media: Bank Board Appointee Faces Conflict Charge; Proxmire Opposes Henkel for S&L Ties; Bank Board Appointee Faces Conflict Charge by Proxmire

Lee Henkel, who joined the Federal Home Loan Bank Board two months ago via a recess appointment by President Reagan, is embroiled in a conflict-of-interest charge that lies at the heart of a fight over control of the Bank Board and ultimately the future of the ailing S&L industry.
Media: Henkel Denies Conflict in His S&L Proposal

"At Mr. Henkel's first Board meeting, on Dec. 18, the board rejected a proposal by its Chairman, Edwin J. Gray, to extend for two years a rule limiting a thrift institution's direct real estate investments to 10 percent of its assets.
Mr. Henkel then proposed a more liberal plan that included exempting certain thrift institutions from the retroactive impact of the rule. His plan was also voted down. After the meeting, staff members said privately that only two institutions, one of them Lincoln Savings, would have benefited from the Henkel plan."
Riegle meets with Keating and Grogan in Washington
Fundraising event on Riegle's behalf is discussed (possibly at the Ponchetrain Hotel, where Keating was investing in another tower)
Glenn meets with Attchison to discuss investigation of Keating
Glenn sets this up to substantiate Lincoln's claim that regulators are abusing them and their request for Glenn to talk to them
McCain goes to Riegle's office to talk about the Gray/Keating feud
Media: Lincoln S&L Holds Position as No. 2 in Orange County
America Votes discloses Keating donated $100,000 to start it up
Check sent on Mar. 3. Jacobson keeps Grogan up-to-date with PAC's activity
Letter sent to Jacobson from Grogan re: desire for Gray's dismissal
Grogan wants their advice on the matter. Jacobson says she doesn't remember seeing it
Grogan sends letter to Riegle, Jacobson, and Jordan asking for advice about Petition for Disqualification for Gray
Grogan and Attchison go to Washington to lobby support for "direct investment" deregulation.
Lincoln files lawsuit against "direct investment" laws
Keating calls DeConcini and asks him to set up meeting re: issues with Gray
Not the only time DeConcini had been contacted re: Gray. DeConcini thinks it was a good idea
Riegle talks to McCain on Senate floor re: Keating's issues
They go to Riegle's office after to discuss
AZ League of Savings and Loans Association issues complaint to VanPaasschen re: "direct investment" laws
Riegle meets with Gray re: FSLIC recapitalizaiton bill
Secretary says Gray's office called Riegle
Gray meets with Riegle to lobby for "direct investment" regulation
At the end of the meeting, Riegle tells Gray that there are Senators that want to meet with him about the "direct investment" laws. According to Gray, Riegle says: "You'll be getting a call"

At the end of the visit, Riegle says he will try to set up a meeting with Gray. He also offers that it would help to have constituent Senators present. During the later investigation, Riegle says that the trip to Phoenix was on the pretense of another engagement
While Keating and Rielge meet privately, Grogan discusses fundraiser that Keating proposed for Riegle
Riegle votes against cutting S&L regulatory funding
Arthur Young (Attchison's) letter sent to Riegle
Media: Bank Board Clears Henkel of Conflict Charge; Reagan Nominee Accused of Proposing Self-Serving Amendment

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has cleared Board member Lee Henkel of conflict-of-interest charges concerning a California savings and loan institution the Federal agency regulates, according to an internal bank board document.
Grogan attends meeting with Cranston and Riegle
DeConcini's office recieves Attchison letter and other evidence of mistreatment
Attchison letter was originally sent to Riegle
Arthur Young (Attchison) letter sent to McCain's office
VanPaasschen unaware of office receiving this letter
ACC sends DeConcini's office info. re: regulatory problems and ACC's responses
Includes memo entitled "Talking Points for Meeting with Ed Gray." Written on it: "WON'T USE"
DeConcini talks to Riegle and tells him he is having trouble with Gray
Asks him if he will help. Riegle later says to have meeting with Gray
Grogan meets with Riegle and asks for invite from McCain/DeConcini to attend meeting with Gray
Allegedly where Riegle tells Grogan to have DeConcini invite him
Sedlmayr prepares memo re: ACC's concerns for DeConcini
ACC had sent DeConcini's office a bunch of material; Sedlmayr summarizes and adds editorial to it for DeConcini (believes she did this before meeting with McCain)
McCain, DeConcini, VanPaasschen, and Sedlmayr meet in McCain's office re: Keating and Gray

Dicussed Keating's problems with audit and whether a meeting with Gray would be productive. McCain doesn't commit to DeConcini's suggestion to go to SF Regulators. DeConcini offers to go to Gray's office right there and then. McCain tells VanPaasschen afterwards he thinks that's inappropriate
VanPaasschen advises McCain that meeting with Gray and the SF Regulators would be improper
DeConcini recieves summary of Keating's positions via "Schedule" memo
DeConcini calls Gray and asks if he will meet with the Senators re: Lincoln's problems with the Bank Board
Gray says he will be happy to and they set the time. "No aides" was not mentioned in the conversation
Petition filed to recuse Gray from the Bank Board
Fundraiser by Keating for Riegle held at his Ponchetrain Hotel
VanPaasschen has long conversation with Attchison about the legitimacy of his letter
Sedlmyer tells VanPaasschen that Keating called McCain a "wimp" in conversaiton with DeConcini
Keating and McCain meet in McCain's office
McCain tells Keating he won't intervene for him. The two had a falling out
VanPaasschen sends memo to McCain that supports Authur Young letter (after meeting with Keating)
Memo includes info. that she got from Attchison: According to McCain, this research happens during the meeting with Keating (when he says he won't talk to Gray for him)
Riegle votes again on the Senate floor to protect funding for S&L regulators
McCain tells VanPaasschen that there is duscussion of four Senators meeting with Gray
Names the four Senators that will be involved; says DeConcini agreed to discussion points
Media: Justice Asked to Probe Bank Board Member; Justice Asked to Probe Henkel
The Justice Department has been asked to determine if a top savings and loan regulator used his government office to try to benefit an S&L that has lent him millions of dollars.
Sedlmayr sends DeConcini memo in preparation for April 2nd meeting
Date when McCain says he finds out other Senators will be at meeting with Gray
Media: Henkel Resigns FHLBB Post, Criticizes Justice Dept. Probe; Henkel Quits Bank Board
Meeting 1: McCain, DeConcini, Cranston, and Glenn meet w/ Gray in DeConcini's office
First of the five Senator's meetings, VanPaasschen sits outside. Riegle is not in attendance. According to Gray, Reigle first summonsed him to this meeting
McCain recieves memo outlining two points he can talk about in meeting with Gray (from VanPaasschen)
Keating sends "Schedule" memo to other Senators
Grogan goes to Washington after the first meeting to talk to all the Senators and "keep the team together"
Keating tells him to "keep the team together" and tell all the Senators how important attendance at the second meeting is to Keating
Gray calls DeConcini to tell him that regulators will meet with Senators on the 9th
DeConcini's office calls the other Senators' schedulers to let them know
Riegle tells DeConcini to ask Sedlmayr not to contact his office re: meetings with Gray
Riegle's scheduler said he knew nothing about Riegle's involvement with the Gray meeting
Sedlmayr calls friend in Riegle's office to find out about his involvement in the matter
The friend says he knows nothing about the meeting. DeConcini tells Sedlmayr that Rielge asked her not to contact his office about the matter
DeConcini calls Gray and tells him the Senators do want to meet with the SF Regulators
Sedlmayr drafts letter to Riegle inviting him to second meeting, from DeConcini and McCain
Letter is only signed by DeConcini; Sedlmayr later testifed she thought the letter was unusual as it was her impression that the meeting was Riegle's idea
Meeting 2: Five Senators meet with SF Regulators in DeConcini's office
McCain only asks about length of exam and fairness; Cranston attends only part of meeting due to business on Senate floor
Sedlmayr meets with Grogan on the day of the April 9th meeting
Both McCain and Glenn end all contact with Keating and SF Regulators
Jordan visits ACC (to look at their operation and land valuation etc.)
Invited by Grogan, paid for by CA Thrift and Loan who she was making a speach for
DeConcini calls Keating and tells him he can't expect much from the Bank Board
Gray sends Riegle copy of Black Transcript
Riegle ends all contact with Keating and SF Regulators
Except to later return contributions raised by Keating in early 1988
Exam Report on Lincoln issued by SF Regulators
Gray's term on the Bank Board ends
M. Danny Wall appointed new Chairman
Keating offers to raise another $150,000 for Glenn
Media: S&L Chief Says Bank Board Leaked Data to Discredit Him; S&L Executive Sues Bank Board

A California savings and loan executive who has feuded for years with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has filed suit accusing the agency of leaking confidential financial information to discredit him and ruin his business.
Jacobson schedules meeting with Keating and Cranston for this date
Jacobson says Keating is happy about Wall being appointed the new FHLBB Chairman. She then suggests that Cranston "should ask Keating for $250,000"
Jordan hears Bank Board is making a criminal referral to the Justice Department re: Lincoln
Glenn sets up a luncheon between Keating, Wright, and himself
Jacobson schedules dinner for Cranston and Keating
Keating surprises Cranston with $500,000 in checks

Cranston and Grogan talk via telephone about Lincoln
For an annual salary of approximately $900,000

Bank Board and Lincoln enter into public Memorandum of Understanding
Media: THE SAVINGS AND LOAN CRISIS; Edwin Gray on the S&L Crisis 'This Was a Self-Inflicted Disaster'

What was once a dirty little secret is now headline news: The American taxpayer will have to foot a bill, estimated at between $50 billion and $100 billion, to pay for the profligate pursuits of savings and loan operators.
Keating calls DeConcini to make request (DeConcini says no)

Asks for DeConcini to call new FHLBB Chairman Wall and see if he will hold the audit and push for approval of Lincoln's sale. Keating needs more time to sell the company to keep ACC viable. Instead, DeConcini just makes a status inquiry
Jordan, Cranston, and Keating have dinner
Keating says he's getting out of the business
DeConcini sends Sedlmayr memo re: sale of Lincoln
DeConcini seems to express genuine concern about general state of AZ economy, not just political favor to Keating

Grogan talks about Lincoln's intent to sell; seeking help in getting Bank Board to approve the sale
Wants to check on why the Bank Board is involved in selling this early (if Lincoln is a healthy company, as she thought). Dochow says Lincoln's net worth is in dispute
Sedlmayr sends memo to DeConcini re: meeting with Grogan
Drafts talking points for call with new FHLBB Chairman Wall
DeConcini calls new FHLBB Chairman Wall and other members
To push for approval of sale of Lincoln

Sedlmayr drafts response to Gray-McCain letter for DeConcini

Media: Keating, Failed King of Thrifts, Lincoln S & L's Deposed Chief, Blasting Back at the Regulators
Federal officials say the taxpayer bailout of Keating's bankrupt Lincoln Savings and Loan - one of hundreds of failed thrifts nationwide - could cost every man, woman and child in America $10 each.
